name: Neon
educationalNotes: Neon lights up in distinctive red/orange glow - iconic in Vegas signs and art! Inert noble gas that doesn't react with anything. Discovered in 1898. Neon is 24× more abundant than helium but rarer than you'd think. Liquid neon is used in cryogenic applications. Neon's glow comes from electrons jumping energy levels - same physics powers LEDs but neon predates them by decades. High-voltage electricity excites neon atoms, making them emit photons.
